5.2.1
Subject to sub-Clause 5.2.5 below and in the event the Representatives (i) fail to create such committee or (ii) do not agree on an amicable settlement immediately from the date the committee referred to in this sub-Clause 5.2 has been created or such longer period as may be agreed upon in writing by the Representatives (the “Amicable Settlement Period”), the Dispute shall be exclusively and finally settled under the Rules and Conciliation of Arbitration of the International Chamber of Commerce (the “ICC”) by an arbitral tribunal composed of three (3) arbitrators; each Party shall then appoint one (1) arbitrator within 24 hours from the last day of the Amicable Settlement Period and the third arbitrator, who will act as President, will be appointed by the other two (2)
arbitrators. In case the two (2) arbitrators appointed by the Parties do not agree on this choice with 24 hours from the date the last
arbitrator is appointed, the third arbitrator will be appointed by the ICC Court.
perturbation.explanation: Setting the time limit to come to an amicable settlement as 'immediately' and also the appointment of arbitrators within 24 hours is unreasonable and might be seen as contradictory to due process rights under New York law, especially considering the complexity of disputes that might arise in such a maintenance agreement. Courts in New York may refuse to enforce such strict timelines.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York law regarding due process, enforceability of arbitration clauses

perturbation.changed_text:
5.2
Arbitration: in the event of a dispute arising out of or relating to this Amendment, including without limitation disputes regarding the existence, validity or termination of this Amendment (a “Dispute”), either Party may notify such Dispute to the other through verbal communication (the “Notice of Dispute”). The Parties shall immediately come to a settlement. Such committee shall be created by the Parties whenever the party wants.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the written notice requirement and stating that Parties shall immediately come to a settlement contradicts fundamental principles of contract law relating to dispute resolution. New York law, which governs the agreement, generally requires clear communication and a reasonable opportunity to respond in dispute resolution processes. This could make the arbitration clause unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York contract law, principles of due process
